title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
section: Has predictive processing gone too far?
text:
Has predictive processing gone too far?

YES


in the case of the flash-lag effect


So this is a rather narrow topic, but I think there may be similar dynamics happening in other literatures. You tell me

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
Co-authors (but not co-conspirators)
 
Josh Corbett
Tim Cottier (QUT)
Jye Marchant (U-Syd)

Don’t blame them My co-authors do not necessarily endorse everything I’m going to say in this talk. With apologies to all the great work at Monash and UMelb that’s been done on predictive processing

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
The flash-lag effect


Just explain the demo, don’t editorialise yet

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
The predictive processing account
The brain extrapolates the position of the moving object, to compensate for neural latency (Nijhawan 1994)


I’m not going to deny that extrapolation occurs. My point will be more that if it does exist it may only be a bit player in the cavalcade of contributors to the FLE

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text: Predictive processing has become very popular in my field of vision science, which is fine, except that it had lead to some shoehorning of all sorts of phenomena into the predictive processing framework, which can sometimes hold back pogress on them.

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
section: Has predictive processing gone too far?
text:
Has predictive processing gone too far?

the FLE is an example of extrapolation that forecasts an object’s future position according to its current velocity

Rust & Palmer (2021), Annual Review of Vision Science

This effect the flash-lag effect is due to extrapolation of the moving object resulting in the moving object being perceived ahead in time

Teichmann et al (2021), Trends in Cognitive Science

In the words of our first keynote speaker, “I’m here to mess up this nice pretty picture.” And also to suggest a way forward
16 papers (those that don’t have “NA” in the “Explanation” column, see Appendix A), only two of the articles mentioned other theories.

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
Of 16 papers in 2023 that mentioned the FLE, only 2 articles mentioned theories besides the extrapolation theory

not cherry-picking there

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
Problems for the predictive account

Flash-terminated condition
Flash-initiated condition
Extrapolation proponents admit that extrapolation can’t explain these

Invoke postdiction, declare victory again
Other possible contributors are referred to as “modulators”



Postdiction might indeed be occurring. But it is used as a catch-all to explain away any contrary evidence, so it smacks of special pleading
I think this is a bit too quick, especially when one considers that there are many more findings that they can’t explain.

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
section: Problems for the predictive account: Predictability not required
text:
Problems for the predictive account: Predictability not required

Randomly-jumping bar shows the same phenomenon (Murakami, 2000, 2001)
Feature space “motion” highly unlikely to be predicted by the brain also yields the phenomenon (Sheth & Shimojo, 2000; Callahan-Clintoft, Holcombe, & Wyble, 2020)

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
section: Problems for the predictive account: High variability
text:
Problems for the predictive account: High variability

The variability is as large as the mean (Murakami 2000, 2001; Linares, Holcombe, & White 2009)

Bad for position perception! 12 kph (7.5 mph), 80 ms of trajectory = 27 cm

Individuals’ mean flash-lag effects vary dramatically

8 out of 85 in Cottier et al. (2023) were negative in both sessions

Extrapolation occurs only later, not online (Nakayama & Holcombe 2021; Nakayama, Amano, & Murakami 2025)


People talk about the first two, and then invoke postdiction, which is a loosey-goosey way to explain any results one can’t account for.

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
section: The task has a temporal component
text: The task has a temporal component

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
Temporal errors

Triggered sample / attention shift
Intermittent updating
Temporal mis-binding


I think everybody here has heard of brain oscillations
attention shift temporal integration brain oscillation

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
Temporal mis-binding
Moutoussis & Zeki (1997)

Initially suggested to be difference in neural latency

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
Temporal mis-binding
  Moutoussis & Zeki (1997)

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
Temporal mis-binding

“Thus the color-motion asynchrony appears to result from the binding process favoring the early phase of the color but not the early part of the motion.” - Holcombe (2009)

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
What causes the FLE?

Temporal error? LIKELY

Triggered sample / attention shift
Intermittent updating
Temporal mis-binding

Extrapolation / predictive processing? LIKELY - but not based on FLE evidence


This is me being nice. Where it’s gone too far is in writing as if extrapolation is the cause of the FLE And

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text: The fallacy of the single cause

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
section: The fallacy of the single cause
text:
The fallacy of the single cause

Please stop saying that the FLE is caused by extrapolation

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
Please stop saying that the FLE is caused by extrapolation
If you want to find good evidence for extrapolation, don’t study the flash-lag effect



The flash-lag effect is the worst one to study, if you’re interested in extrapolation / predictive processing

title: ACNS2025notesIntoSlides
text:
Other accounts
 ::: notes ::: - Triggered sample / attention shift - Temporal mis-binding - Intermittent updating - Discrete sampling / brain oscillation :::
